body:
Just because MsgUtils is internal doesn't mean we couldn't provide a method for you to inject a formatter. Can you explain more about how you would want to reformat messages and why it is needed for FsUnit?

One thing that you need to be aware of is that NUnit needs to compile back to .NET 2.0, so you won't be able to use a Func, but will need to create a new delegate.

I am tagging this as an idea for discussion and design.

F# has a few types (records, tuples, discriminated unions) that from .NET perspective are just objects. These types however have nice support when F#'s own [printf module functions](https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/ee370560.aspx) are used to format the values.

So, for example, asserting the equality of two records of type MyRecord (all of the above mentioned types are equattable in F#, btw) with default .NET formatting will tell me something like "[MyRecord] is not equal to [MyRecord]", while formatted with printf will be a lot more informative: "{field1:10} is not equal to {field1:20}".

In general though, you'd be able to address large group of "this format is not to my liking" scenarios, like #1004 with a pluggable formatter.

That sounds reasonable. I would accept a pull request for that, but first I would like to get an idea on how you would propose adding this. I am changing the milestone to backlog and the status to design.

Instead of a Func/delegate what about an interface for a custom formatter with a format method and a property or method that specifies the `Type` that the formatter handles? End users could implement the interface and pass the `Type` to NUnit which would instantiate it and call it where needed. This type could be passed in an assembly attribute or NUnit could also find all implementations of the interface when it explores the tests.

Another option could be an assembly attribute that takes a delegate and a .NET type that the delegate should format.
@rprouse Alternatively, we could leave the feature out of the .NET 2.0 build.

It may be overkill for this use case, but this might be useful for NUnit itself. I could see us migrating all of our formatters out to a custom formatter per type while still allowing end users to override or add their own formatters.

So, as long as users can add to an already existing chain of formatters, I would be cool with it.

issue.title: NUnit 3.x support

repository.name: FsUnit
repository.description: FsUnit makes unit-testing with F# more enjoyable. It adds a special syntax to your favorite .NET testing framework.

issue.body: Pretty please? Is there anything to do here beyond bumping the version?

repository.name: FsUnit
repository.description: FsUnit makes unit-testing with F# more enjoyable. It adds a special syntax to your favorite .NET testing framework.

issue.title: Issue 1196
issue.body:
This PR fixes #1196 and replaces PR #1198, which was withdrawn by its creator @et1975.

The initial commit includes the original code from that PR plus a fix to ensure that a check for a null value is done before any custom formatters are called. This means that it is not possible to add a special display format for `null` but in compensation avoids any issues with formatters that make use of the value without checking.

Further commits will make this available through the TestContext. I'm not yet sure whether we need to keep the static method for use by F#. From some of @et1975 's comments, that seems to be the case, but he never explained how the feature would be used from F#, only that he didn't want to use it from a OneTimeSetUp method.

F# folks: you can help us here. The OP has left the scene, so there's a good chance we will end up creating something that is not useful to you unless somebody else is willing to communicate. :-)

body:
Perhaps while massive changes are being made to MsgUtils, #1004 can be addressed at the same time?

Just need to add FormatDateTimeOffset method and the appropriate factory call for it to add it to the formatter chain.

Usually, we do better with many small issues and PRs but that one might be small enough to slip in here. This PR already combines two things, but the implementations were mutually influencing each other so I decided to keep them together.

issue.title: Pretty-print F# value types using NUnit 3.2 custom formatters

repository.name: FsUnit
repository.description: FsUnit makes unit-testing with F# more enjoyable. It adds a special syntax to your favorite .NET testing framework.

issue.body:
``` fsharp
TestContext.AddFormatter(ValueFormatterFactory(fun _ -> ValueFormatter(sprintf "%A")))
```

depends on https://github.com/nunit/nunit/milestones/3.2
implemented in https://github.com/nunit/nunit/issues/1196
